bibl.title: Letter from Juan Guiteras to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 2, 1908

div1.p: Guiteras discusses his hesitancy to publicize yellow fever cases.

div1.head: Letter from Juan Guiteras to Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 2, 1908
div1.opener:
From Dr. Juan Guiteras
Dr. Finlay to
read
REPUBLIC OF CUBA
____
UNDER THE PROVISIONAL ADMINISTRATION OF THE
UNITED STATES
________
OFFICE OF SPECIAL COMMISSIONER NATIONAL
SANITARY DEPARTMENT
____
Sept 2/08.
Dear Major Kean;
div1.p:
you have received
my telegram by this time. I did
not care to place it in the telegram,
but Major Fauntelroy is going to
Antilla apparently to judge from
what he says, to bulldoze Dr.
Cartoya into holding his tongue
if he discovers any thing. He stated
here this afternoon that he is to
ask you to keep these aspects
from around him.

The man, I should have added,
had again nose bleed this morning.

I intended to go on this morn-
ing to Havana tomorrow morning
but there is a suspicious case from
Antilla at the Hospital, and
as there is a chance for a
post mortem I think I shall
stay. The case I think is
negative.
